annotation.TEXT: Beyond that, screen transitions also seem to cause some issues in this game as well. It has the same problem Limelight 2 had in that when you transition to a new screen, your movements are locked if you were holding down on a direction (though here, it's somehow even less responsive).

Also, Ballade likes to zone out from time to time. I'm not sure what causes this, nor am I certain as to what causes the other glitch I encountered the first time I fought him (where he literally left the boundaries of the room, forcing me to reset).

As you can probably tell by now, the invincibility frames you get after being hit wear out way too quickly. This can actually lead to instances of being stun-locked by the same enemy, taking out more of your life or outright killing you with no way to fight back. It also doesn't help that Mega Man is pushed back further with longer recoil than usual.

Jolt Man's stage is easily one of the most annoying levels in the game. The main reason for this is not only due to the somewhat chaotic nature and layout of the stage itself, but also because of how poorly introduced certain gimmicks are (electrified floors, timed blocks, and falling platforms are all crammed into areas with little to no proper introduction).
Nice death pose, bro.

Jolt Shocker is pretty basic in functionality. It's a straight-forward projectile with decent size and high firing speed. The nice thing about it however, is that it rapidly damages enemies while passing through them. This can also work on a few shielded enemies as well (Sniper Joes included).

Ballade himself is actually pretty easy for the most part (aside from his annoying tendency to run directly into you). The only major threat in this fight is that you only get one shot at beating him, which goes for the rest of the Mega Man Killers as well. If you lose all your life while fighting one, you don't necessarily die, but you lose your chance at fighting them and obtaining their weapon (though you can still buy them in the shop if you happen to lose).

The second part of this stage switches things up a bit, mainly by introducing puzzles where you need to redirect electric shots. Honestly, if the whole stage had more of these elements to it, I probably wouldn't find it as annoying to get through (though you can still easily get hit by the electric shots themselves as you're trying to shoot the arrows).

Frigid Frost is a decent weapon in practice, but it tends to be unreliable most of the time. It fires out a single chunk of ice that bursts into many smaller pieces after hitting something. Much like Frigid Man's version however, these spread shots fly out in random directions. Aside from weakness affiliations, dealing any kind of moderate damage with this thing is more luck-based than anything.
This mini-boss isn't much better (both in the animation and health department). Never-mind the fact that it's also a scaled up, slightly edited version of the seal enemy from Mega Man 6.

So then, how to start this off? This particular fan-game has been in the works for quite some time (around 6 years, to be exact). Taking the time to complete a project of this magnitude is certainly a commendable effort, but then again, that's not what I'm here to talk about. The main point is: How did the final product itself turn out?

Fun fact: The bouncing projectiles this mini-boss produces can suddenly defy their intended patterns, thereby flying in a straight line or converging on a completely different path than their normal ones.

As said before, Frigid Man is the easiest of the Robot Masters, though his fight isn't without its faults. His projectiles tend to break apart and fly off in random directions. The fact that they blend in with the background also doesn't help much.

Yes, there's absolutely no vertical scrolling in this section. Mercifully, this is the only spike drop in the entire game. In either case, this section also holds a letter as well. Collecting all of them will give you access to Beat (who you need to obtain if you want to unlock some of this game's secrets).

Instead of Ballade Cracker, we get "Ballade Missile" for winning this fight. It functions almost like Ballade's original weapon, only now you can't fire it out in 8 directions. Instead, you can only aim it straight forward or up and down in slight arcs. It's easily one of the strongest weapons in the game, having high damage output and good ammo reserves to boot.

Frigid Man is probably one of the best starting points in this game (despite his stage opening with a rather awful spike drop segment). Aside from being the easiest of the Robot Masters, his weapon is decent enough at first (though it'll soon be eclipsed by far better options).

This stage also includes several instances of Sniper Joes, which are also among the most annoying enemies in the game. They have no clear firing pattern, and the opportunity you get to hit them is minuscule at best. I would just take a hit and pass by them under normal circumstances...but that leads me to another major issue this game has: the invincibility time.

Jolt Man himself isn't exactly a walk in the park either. While his pattern is relatively simple (jump, fire projectiles forward, repeat), he can easily get into the habit of spamming his stronger projectile variation, which involves raining down lightning bolts from the ceiling. It also doesn't help that he seems to have some arbitrary invincibility frames during some of the charge-up's on his attacks.
If you consider the graphics (which are actually sketches) in this intro to be foreshadowing, then you already have a good idea of what this game's overall quality is like.

Uhh...Photon Man? Alright then, I like Kevin's "Stage 45" theme well enough, but it seems a bit too cheery for a guy like Ballade. Either way, this the first Mega Man Killer stage in the game. After beating two Robot Masters, one of them shows up on the select screen. You can't pick any other stage but their's when this happens (though you can still revisit previously beaten stages).

Time to get right to the basics of this game, and I'm not going to skip around the issues: The controls are very awkward to get used to. Mega Man himself moves around and slides just fine, but several problems start to creep up with pretty much everything else. Jumping is ultra stiff, making it frustrating to do any form of precision platforming.

Though already exemplified before with the Red Devil, this fridge in particular really showcases how off some of the animations are in this game. That's also not to mention that it's among the most resilient enemies as well (it takes way too many hits to kill, even with some of the strongest weapons).
